WRITING.TEXT: Hell yah! Sober people ain't a free taxi service!
Have you tried being social without alcohol? It's not as easy, but it comes without self-loathing and hangovers.

I am curious as to how you think people recover from alcohol abuse. It seems that you think it's more than just not drinking.
For me I got so exhausted. My last drunk was terribly emotional and something kind of snapped inside me and I went "Yaaaah I dunno if I can do this anymore"
And I loooved being fucked up.
I kind of tricked myself into going to rehab and it worked. I signed up, went through the motions with little to zero resolve to stop...but then I got there and went "Ok. Well I guess I can try"
But it wasn't something I could just do on my own. I believe I needed serious inpatient help. I had very strong habits and patterns that needed to be broken.

I wrote a big long thing and then I realized, I wasn't really being helpful.
I'm sorry you're losing friends. It's hard. I hope you find some relief soon.
Staying sober doesn't always feel worth it. But I guess it's long term health and happiness.

Sometimes small efforts build into massive shifts. A 20 minute walk after dinner was the start of my dad getting on track with losing weight, getting off blood pressure medication, learning to meditate, getting a new job, and turning his outlook on life around.
My recovery didn't happen in one day with giant life altering decisions.
It was OK, never drink. Ever. Then it was "first things first" and "easy does it"
I like your attitude!!
MMMmmmMmM!!!
The first year or so I went to AA meetings or my outpatient group at night. After work I generally learned how to start winding down. I went for walks, I browsed SD, I went to the gym.

"Blueberries are healthy"
*adds ice cream*
I skipped gym and went for a walk instead too! Weird!

I feel like missing it for the taste would be part 1 of relapse for me. "I wanted to taste it again" is something I can imagine myself saying sitting in rehab for the second time. No thanks. I'll stick to water.

My name is Victoria. You have consent to use what I write in this comment.
I found SD by searching around reddit for recovery subreddits. I found SD and really liked the vibe. It was more laid back than some of the other subreddits and seemed to have a different way of being.
What I like about SD is that there are so many different people here. Not everyone here says that they are alcoholic, and many don't even use that terminology. I don't. There are binge drinkers here, people in college who worry about their consumption...there are older people, younger people...I think what's cool is that we share a common theme: that we have a relationship with alcohol that makes us or others unhappy.
I love SD with all my heart. I think it's such a cool place. The kindness people show total strangers is a testament to how recovery can bring people together.

*To media: all media organizations are asked to contact reddit users before they use a story. Although this may be an open forum, we ask that you respect this space and the wishes of SD members. This post is to give an idea of what SD is like: not for you to publish their stories without consent.*

WRITING.TITLE: Weekend Writing: A call for submissions
WRITING.TEXT:
Recently we've been getting more and more interest from media organizations. The truth is, as we grow, we're going to get more and more attention. Online recovery tools, apps, are all booming.
The mods are in the midst of creating a sort of press package more robust than [this](https://www.reddit.com/r/stopdrinking/wiki/index#wiki_media).
In reality, the SD members, your stories, encouragement, sharing and kindness are *what makes SD special*.
**Your experiences are what people are interested in, and as mods, we cannot recreate your experiences or speak for you.**
So we'll do our part and explain the guidelines, community development and history.
So we're asking you, if you want to, let us know about SD and it's impact on you.
**To keep yourself safe when responding, please remember to be mindful of the amount you disclose and what you're comfortable sharing. In theory, media organizations and outlets should be asking for your consent before they use content you share, but this doesn't always happen. [Reddit rules on it here](https://reddit.zendesk.com/hc/en-us/articles/206630455-Press-Media)**
It's your turn to speak. How did you get here? How do you use SD? What do you like about it? What's your experience with SD?
This thread will be kept up for the weekend, and then it will be linked along with a small press package on the sidebar.
Gym. Laundry. Blueberry crumble.
I'm not sure anyone deserves it. But people use past behaviour as a marker for current behaviour. After two weeks, I couldn't expect people to expect I was sober.
I'm so sorry you're hurting so much. I feel that under the fear and pain is the belief that you're a competent, responsible woman. I hope one day you're able to see that.
It took some time for my brain to get back to normal. Regular exercise and good nutrition helped me feel more balanced.
Doctors won't just check you into inpatient detox without your consent :) Unless you're a danger to yourself or others! It's extremely difficult to force people into inpatient treatment.
Why have I never thought of orange slices? Smart move!
That sounds terribly painful. Glad you're here.
Hey hope to see you back today! How are the withdrawals today? Any improvement?
Congrats man :)
Don't need AA to get sober. There are many pathways. Welcome to sd.
Like attracts like. We're all magnets and mirrors of each other in my opinion. Humans are weird!
Please speak from the I.
Good job man!

You're not an odd one out here for quitting.
Culture is relative.
It was hard for me to break away from the "drinker" persona. But she didn't bring me any happiness. Just pain. I wanted more than hangovers, regret, debt and terrible health.

For me, being drunk felt being better than being sober.
I would start withdrawing if I didn't drink for 7-8 hours. So it was like...I believed I couldn't stop, because the withdrawals were so nasty. Plus mentally and emotionally I'd be nasty.
It makes rational sense to stop drinking. Like I did a pros and cons analysis, and the only pro to drinking was "Get drunk" but that was SO FUCKING REWARDING that it outweighed alllll the cons.
What happened to me is that I was pretty lucky. I didn't die, I didn't kill myself, and I managed to trick myself into going to rehab under the guise of "I need to get these people off my back, they are so annoying"
I had a very small voice in my head telling me that I might be worth getting sober, and I kind of followed that. In the beginning I just put some things into action (filling out paperwork for rehab, seeing my doctor, making a treatment plan) without actually wanting it.
I think I knew at one point I knew that I was going to want to get help. I just had to wait for that moment. I woke up on May 27th 2011 after my last drunk, and just knew that that was it. I can honestly say 24 hours before this, I would have wanted to drink.
Since I had planned, albeit unenthusiastically, a treatment plan: I went to rehab on June 1st and haven't looked back.
No worries man. Come back soon. Detox is brutal but you never have to go through it again.
Hi there we don't allow anyone to post while drinking. I know you're trying to stave of DT's, but come back tomorrow and we'll be here.
I stayed close to sober people, places and things in early recovery. It helped me immensely.
Not a bummer at all. SD is free and available all the time :) I hope you get some relief soon from your troubles!
Damn right I am! Thank you!
I should be dead or dying of an STD in jail. I am not. This is crazy.

I remember this happening to me. Still does some days.
When I am angry, pissed off, completely out of my mind and I don't use drugs/alcohol/food to CHANGE the way I feel...I am rewarded with the most natural rush. I did it. I surfed the wave. I got out alive.
I believe that moments like this are defining points in recovery. The ability to get through these difficult, confusing days is HUGE.
Maybe you just had an emotional day. Human behaviour is terribly complex and multifaceted. Trying to pin down the exact reason has driven me insane!
I was sober and present at my wedding and regret nothing. I spent thousands on that day. I want to remember every fucking moment I can!
The mods are just so thrilled about your saga. We just love you man.

I say "I don't drink"
It's no one's business that I am in recovery from substance abuse.
You're an amazing woman with a big support network. I hope you find some relief soon and are able to forgive yourself. No one is perfect.

I didn't realize I had a problem until I was sitting in rehab. It was the first time someone had asked me if I thought I had a problem. I was so used to people telling me I had one.
Then I kind of looked back on the last 5 years of my life and realized that wow, I had a problem.
Sounds like she would be comfortable and happy there.
Have you asked her what she wants from her rehab?
What do you think? I am not a fan of the term dry drunk I find it overly judgemental. It's not fair to paint someone's entire recovery with a broad brush.

I honestly hated myself and was not sure I deserved a good life. So for me it made sense that I was slowly trying to kill myself with booze.
When I quit I was listening to that tiny voice in my head that said "Hey you might be worth it"
Dumping the hidden stuff. That's commitment man. Welcome.

Oh I haven't had PAWS in years. I meant I got hit with anxiety and agitation at my one year celebration.
I wish I could say that anxiety naturally goes away, but I have a diagnosis of Generalized Anxiety Disorder. Some of my earliest memories involve anxiety. So it's just something I deal with. I've been medication-free for over 1.5 years, and that's huge for me.
Sobriety and lifestyle management make my anxiety infinitely easier to deal with.
My life is sort of kittens and rainbows though. I say that because I honestly think my life is pretty good, despite the things I struggle with. It's all about perspective and attitude.

I meditate to hopefully sort of stave off or prevent outbursts. I am sure that's a terribly un-meditative way of looking at mindfulness, but hey, I ain't perfect.
When I am agitated, I generally need to move. I find forcing myself to relax is a losing battle. Just my experience.
As for PAWS, it's totally individual. I found that I got hit with PAWS at 3 weeks, 1 month, 3 months, 6 months and then a huge hit of anxiety at 1 year. Is it PAWS? Is it just the perils of regular human adult life? Who knows.
That's how I got started. Making a few phone calls and wondering what the fuck was going on in my life. I hope you find some relief soon.
Please see a doctor we cannot answer medical questions.
Methadone and alcohol have complicated and sometimes dangerous interactions. Please don't attempt to give medical advice.

I do a lot of things when I am bored
- go for a walk
- talk to someone
- clean something
- write
- knit a few rows
- walk around the mall
Tired
- rest
- have water
- light exercise
- go for a walk
- watch something relaxing
For mindfulness I read the book "Wherever you go there you are" by John Kabat Zinn. I don't really have any exercises.

I find realizing that I am bored/tired/hangry is the first step. After that, I have a decision. Drinking is a conscious choice, although it always seems automatic as fuck. In between being bored and drinking there is a choice.
So in early days I had a plan if I were to get bored, or tired, or hungry. Then the trick was actually doing it. Because I didn't drink because I was bored, I drank because I wanted to get drunk.

I couldn't quit drinking on my own and have a non-miserable life. I needed to work on myself.
I think addiction has roots in biology, psychology, the social realm, the spiritual realm and the cultural realm. As well as learning and habit playing a huge role.
So I approach my recovery in the same way.
Biologically I detoxed, saw a doctor, drank water, avoided all things with alcohol in them.
Psychologically I talked about my problem with a therapist and with others, I learned how to self-regulate with DBT and mindfulness.
Socially I found new peer groups and dismantled my idealized and romantic view of alcohol.
Spiritually: this has changed and morphed for me. It's been a very personal journey from hardcore atheism to just respecting people and having compassion.
Culturally I am still figuring out where I fit in.
Long post: but I guess what I am saying is, I had to do stuff to stay sober and live a good life. Not drinking was necessary, but not sufficient, in attaining the results I wanted.
Glad you had a good experience!

No worries. I totally understand. I commented because I used to feel the same way.
I have been to Cuba, Hawaii, done multiple road trips, long camping trips and am planning a few overseas trips in the next year.
What I can say helps me is connecting with people in a different way when I am there. Getting into the culture and being true to what I value and respect.
I also pick and choose vacations that aren't meant for partying. In other words, I don't set myself up for failure.

Everyone is allowed to have their opinion. Most of these people are uneducated about the problems that alcohol can cause.
The reality is, most people don't know what is good or bad for them and just follow what society's fads are. There's a new thing going around facebook that whiskey, honey and lemon juice cure colds. Like, where do I even start with that?
As for people being careful around me because I am in recovery, I don't make myself look like a victim. I tell people I am in recovery from substance abuse. If someone talks about how wasted they got on the weekend and realize I am there, sometimes I'll get a "Omg sorry I forgot you don't drink." I'll just say "Man, it's all good. It doesn't bug me. Sounds like a fun weekend"
Balancing confusion and disorientation with a beverage that confuses and disorients sounds like the opposite of balance to me!
I went to a 35 day inpatient stay and loved it. It was really hard, but really worth it. I needed the structure and the constant 24/7 support from professionals. I was a mess on my own.
Alcohol is a drug. I liked NA meetings as well. I found they were less snobby.

Bartending and waitressing made me extremely good in high stress environments. I thrive under pressure. I just had to learn how to unwind in healthy and constructive ways. Our ability to multitask and talk to strangers are highly transferable skills!!!
I hate when fun spending money turns into boring spending money. I feel your pain.

I know many people who stayed in the industry after they got into recovery. I know I was able to start bartending and waitressing again after some time away. It was never as "fun" again and I ended up changing careers.
At the end of the day, I had to make a decision. Do I want to continue being the party person, or is it time to take some ownership of my health and well-being?
I chose to take care of my health and alcohol problem. I haven't regretted it. Friends and career will always change. I cannot rely on my body regenerating from constant benders.
Depends. Is it an exercise is constantly self-shaming and retraumatizing? Or is there movement towards healing?
Hi there please only post when sober. You matter. We'll be here tomorrow to listen.
Hi there please remove the link to cripplingalcoholism. We do it out of respect for their community.
Could you just be getting sick?
Haaaa! Love it!!

Please don't post as you drink. We are not doctors and at this point only a doctor could give you any clear path in terms of managing severe withdrawal symptoms.
Hallucinations are a symptom of delirium tremens. Not your typical withdrawal. A trip to the ER could save your sanity or life.
We have friends over. Lots of food. It's been fun :)
The best tips are offered on your country or region's guidelines for responsible drinking. Most public health websites will offer some tips. Good luck!
Not appropriate. Detox is not the only answer. The ER, tapering, calling your doctor are all others options.
Please speak from your experience.
I'm going to the Bucks versus Raptors game in Toronto! Then going out with some friends and eating!

WRITING.TITLE: Welcome our new mod!!
WRITING.TEXT:
Hey everyone!
Please join us in welcoming our new mod: /u/BadToTheTrombone
We're looking forward to having them on board!
I've had a few people that chose to move away from me. That's their choice and I respect it. I cannot expect everyone to forgive me. I did some shitty things.

I had a two-part plan.
1. Actually recover. Not like, half way it. Drink sometimes, fuck off sometimes, get angry, get defensive, pretend I was better. Actually get honest, open and willing. Do the work, finish rehab, go to outpatient, do the meetings, cry the tears, talk to my family.
2. Forgive myself. Because no one was going to forgive me if I kept carrying around the shame and guilt.
Your link doesn't seem to be working my friend!
Cool, [here's a reset link](http://sd.bot.nu/badgedate/)
Great planning. Sorry to hear you're feeling so low. I remember feeling that way in early days.
Going to Boston in March and cannot wait to get my hands on ALL the flavours! I've only tried grapefruit. Shipped to me from a dear friend :)
You too man! Stay safe and all that jazz!
Cool thanks.
Have you had some success staying sober today?
Hi there, if you've been drinking tonight please come back tomorrow.
Please only post when sober. We will be here tomorrow.
Please come back when you're sober.

I used to think that being an "alcoholic" was unfair. I learned that there are way more unfortunate physical, mental and spiritual problems.
With alcohol, all I need to do is not drink it. It's not like a mental illness in a lot of ways: I don't find there is a lot of everyday maintenance, I can choose to relapse (whereas depression and anxiety sometimes come back without warning).
Substance abuse isn't a cancer. It's not diabetes. It's not a lifelong drudgery that I need to drag my ass through everyday.
I don't drink, and my life is better. How much better I make it is just like anything else in life: interest, motivation and effort.
If you are considering suicide, please check out /r/SuicideWatch as they are much better at talking to people than we are.
I honestly don't think I could have recovered without my experience in inpatient. It changed how I viewed the world.
I prefer staying sober for important events. What are you thinking about doing tonight?
Things changed for me when I started being honest with myself. It was a big light bulb moment for me.

The chairpeople usually have a list of temporary sponsors.
Other than that I found that going early and helping set up or hang around was the best time to meet people.
How affirming!
A place in Ontario, Canada. I'm not comfortable giving out the name.

Yah it's more confusing eh? Sometimes it's much easier to stop something when it seems SO out of hand.
You mentioned quitting smoking: think you could transfer any of the skills you learned during that time onto the drinking?
For sleep, it's definitely a bummer. The brain becomes accustomed to getting drowsy from alcohol, so it took me some time before I started to fall asleep on my own. I had to actually put effort into sleep and develop good "sleep hygiene" (it's a thing!).
I also used a prescribed medication to help me sleep for the first couple months. It was non-addictive, safe and given to me by my psychiatrist.

Inpatient didn't cost me anything because of insurance.
Inpatient was a 35 night stay. Daily schedule that needed to be followed. Wake up, go for walk with everyone, breakfast, group check in with team (social workers, addiction counsellors, doctor and psychologist). Then we had either a psychoeducational group or a therapy group. Then lunch, then structured leisure time/activity/sport. Then another group therapy meet. Then dinner, then a nightly check, and then sleep.
We had homework, a couple hours a day to chill and play sports or go for walks/exercise. We had three meals a day, healthy. It was awesome. Best thing I've ever done for myself.
I went to outpatient after I did inpatient and had a great experience!
I could quit. I just didn't want to. Do you want to stop?

Many find a daily pledge helps.
For me a daily pledge helps now, but I couldn't have gotten sober with just saying the words. I needed to actually do things during the day that guaranteed a safe and sober arrival home.
I did things like fill up my schedule, have zero alcohol in the house, not drive or walk by liquor stores, not go to bars or restaurants, go to meetings, talk to people about my problems and start loving myself and being accountable to me.
Please speak from your personal experience if you decide to comment. Telling someone to leave or not leave is not how we give support on this subreddit.

you will end up drinking, guaranteed.
Please speak from your personal experience and refrain from telling people they will relapse.

"Don't think about a white bear"
:)
I choose to affirm my craving, recognize it, and realize that it WILL go away.
I totally loved inpatient. It was incredible to be completely involved and dedicated to recovery for 35 days. I wouldn't change my decision.

Do I need to quit AA as not to create a negative impact for those who have relapsed?
I am not responsible for other people's sobriety. And sometimes I think I have more of an impact than I actually do.
We're not doctors and cannot diagnose the severity of your drinking problem.

No one can tell you how to do this. We can only share our personal experiences. Only a doctor can give you advice on whether to cut down or stop completely: and even then, it's really your decision.
I was unable to decrease the amount I was drinking. That was kind of my problem. Cold turkey was painful and uncomfortable, but in my brain, drinking is for getting drunk.
What a great adventure :)

There are lots of options. That person was misinformed.
Outpatient treatment is very popular and a completely effective option.
Please speak from your experience. Your treatment plan won't necessarily work for everyone and it's not ok to tell people what their recovery needs to look like.
I like cauliflower, carrots, peppers, celery, grape tomatoes, radishes, snow peas, peas, mushrooms...
Sorry to hear that. We aren't doctors and have no idea what's going on medically but welcome to sd.

I love this. The concept of building sobriety. If I had to pick some blocks that worked for me
- changing my attitude
- a belief that drinking doesn't ever fix, solve, lessen any problem
- the idea that I'm worthy of living a decent life
